111.content:
This story is about a little boy.
He still wears diapers and is too young to be potty trained, but he is taking a pre-potty training course.
Who is this boy exactly?

Larry Peters: the loving (only) son of Tess and Samuel Peters. They also have a cat called Mary.

Evan Smith: adopted son of his two moms Holly and Lauren. He also has an adopted older sister Lucy, who is nine.
111.title: Pre-Training: Preparations For Potty Usage For ...

choices: He recognized wet or dirty diapers, and wanted to be changed.
He expressed greater desire for autonomy ("me do it!") and imitated others.
He started showing curiosity in the toilet, and can stay dry up to two hours.

Larry was 2, and had begun to show some signs of being ready for potty training, but not all of them.

What signs of readiness was he showing?
1111.title: Larry Peters.

choices: They begin the pre-potty training course.

11111.content:
"Mommy, please change me," said Larry.
"Sure," said Tess, and began to change the boy's diaper.
He'd been good at recognizing when he needed to be changed lately, and he never liked staying in a wet or dirty diaper.
However, he still didn't recognize *needing* to go, so he wasn't ready to be changed yet.

What happens when Tess has finished changing Larry?
11111.title: He recognized wet or dirty diapers, and wanted ...

choices: Change diapers in the bathroom to associate it with the toilet.
Sit child on toilet while bath is filling up/after changes.
Talk more about wet and dry and diapers and the potty.

111111.title: They begin the pre-potty training course.

choices: He's unsure because he's a bit scared of change.

"This is your last change you'll be getting in your room," said Tess.
"Why?" asked Larry.
"Well, your daddy and I are starting a new course for you so that when the time comes, you'll be able to use the toilet instead of a diaper. And the first step is being changed in the bathroom."

What's Larry's response?

11112.content:
"Morning, Larry!" said Samuel.
"Good morning, Daddy," said Larry.
Samuel then began to unbutton Larry's pajama jacket.
"No, me do it!" said Larry, and tried to unbutton it himself, but gave up when he realized he did not know how.

Once Larry was dressed, the two Peters guys went downstairs and saw Tess putting pancakes on the table.
"Look, I'm Mommy," said Larry and set down a plastic toy plate.
This made his parents giggle.

Then, Mary came in, meowing.
"Meow, meow," said Larry.

What happens now?

"Daddy, I need a new diaper," said Larry.
"OK, little boy," said Samuel, "Let's get you changed."
Larry had wet his diaper. The last time he was wet was two hours ago.
As he was being changed in the bathroom, he pointed at the toilet. "What's that?" he asked.
"That's the toilet," said Samuel, "It's what older people use instead of diapers."

What does Larry say?

1112.content: Evan Smith, aged 2 and a half, yawned as he awoke. He was the adopted child of Holly and Lauren Winters. He was taking a course in getting ready to potty train.Where was he now?
1112.title: Evan Smith.

1113.content:
Manny: Having just turned 2, he received some toilet training gifts, like Pull-Ups and books for his birthday. While he isn't *quite* ready to use the potty, he is getting more aware of his body, including finding wet and dirty diapers "icky" and wanting to be changed. Perhaps this can be turned into an interest?

Lloyd: Most kids aren't ready for the potty when they're 1 and a half, and Lloyd is no exception-but with an increasing interest in imitating his parents and elder brother, and his three favorite words being "I do it", some independence may lead him to the potty.
1113.title: Other.

11131.content:
"Happy birthday to you, happy birthday to you, happy birthday dear Manny, happy birthday to you" sang the voices at the birthday party.

They were the birthday boy's parents, Stan and Judy, his friend Alana and her parents Maurie and Elaine, his other friend Max and his father Gabe, and a third friend Rachel, who was accompanied by her parents Fiona and Thomas and her older brother Terrance, making a total of twelve people, including Manny himself.

"Here's a present from your own Mommy and Daddy," said Stan, handing Manny a present. It was pull-ups.
"Diapers?" said Manny.
"They're a special kind of diaper you can use when you're learning to go potty," explained Judy.

Then, Alana said, "This is from me and my Mommy and Daddy."
Manny opened it up: it was some books. "I can't read," said Manny.
Maurie giggled and said, "Your Mommy and Daddy are supposed to read them *to* you."

Next, Fiona said, "And this is from me, Rachel, Thomas, and Terrance."
It was a doll. "Thanks, Fiona," said Manny.

Finally, Gabe handed Manny the present from him and Max: a ball.

What happens now?
11131.title: Manny.

choices: Mike tries to teach Lloyd some words.
Pete gets off the phone and reveals who he'd been talking to.
11132.content:
One day, Samantha Evans was getting ready for work, when she found her one-and-a-half-year-old son Lloyd sitting on the floor, holding a toy car to his ear like a phone and babbling to it.

She looked and saw her husband Pete, Lloyd's father, on the phone.
"I think he's copying your dad, Mike," she said.
The nine-year-old boy in question looked up from the book he was reading and smiled.

What happens now?
11132.title: Lloyd.

Terry breathed a sigh of relief as he heard his mother call. He quickly got up and ran over to his bedroom, all the way firmly pressing his butt cheeks together.

Terry leaned on her shoulders as she helped him step out of them.

“No!” Terry said. Only mommy hadn’t really asked. She scooped him up and sat him down on the dreaded potty. Terry squirmed and wiggled. “I dun hafta go!” he screamed.

Most kids have a cause for their nighttime bathroom problems. For some, it's just genetics-if your parents are bedwetters, you'll likely be one as well.

Sometimes, it's just the way a schedule works, like how a kid has a drink before bed as a routine, or a big gap between the last trip to the potty and bedtime.

Sometimes, it's an thing with drinks-sometimes, sugary or caffinated drinks can make a bladder overactive, or even just too much water at dinner.

And sometimes, it's just a matter of growing out of it.

12221332122.content:
Sara quickly debated going potty in her head, and having convinced herself that the reward for her success would be worth more than the few minutes she would lose while going. As she got up and began walking towards bathroom however, the magnitude of her need really began to register. Even as a part of her mind suggested that she throw in the towel, another part of it rebuked that they were already more than halfway to the potty.
A misplaced step on her way, however, seriously tipped the scales of her fate: As she stumbled, falling to the hallway floor, she felt her concentration waver, moved instead towards catching herself as she fell.
Although her impact far from hurt, as she climbed up off the floor, ready to resume her scramble for the potty, her bowels gave out, emptying themselves into her waiting pull-up.
The shock of her fall, the humiliation of her accident, and her general bitterness and anger at the fact that she had gotten up from her games, (where she could have had a voluntary, controlled ‘accident’) to instead trip and mess her pull-up when she actively tried to make it to the potty this time all combined to overwhelm Sara, causing her to nearly wail in despair.
Both her mother and sister had heard the fall, and came running upstairs to find Sara, in a crawl, with a messy pull-up, crying bitterly.
As the two pulled Sara off the floor, going to comfort her with coos of “Shh, shh, you’re alright Sara, it was just a fall, you’re fine,” Sara only cried harder, whimpering about how she “tried to g-go potty, bu-but I fell, and, and-!”
Upon piecing together Sara’s story, her mother pulled her in close, saying softly, “Oh, Sara, honey, it’s alright. I know you tried to get to the potty. Come on, let’s go get you changed.”

At this, Sara wanted to protest with “But I had one accident,” but she knew this couldn’t be farther from the truth of the matter, she had had a lot of either wet or messy accidents recently, so she kept silent, opting to instead just cry quietly.
As her mother laid her down, steps of the change that would’ve embarrassed her on a normal day now absolutely mortified Sara: The ripping of her pull-up’s tapes seemed to be a thousand times louder, the cool breeze on her nether and the wipes that followed it seemed to be as cold as the harshest winter in her memory. The familiar, but shamefully new scent of baby powder sent waves of guilt rippling through her. But by far the worst step was the ‘new’, thicker padding that her mother taped gently around Sara’s waist. It reminded her of an era she expected to never have to return to, but here she was: A legitimately infantile diaper being put on her for the first time in nearly six months, the shame lessened only by the realization that her pull-ups, which had been hailed as ‘big-girl underwear’ by everyone around her, had been the exact same thing, with only a change of designs.
As her mother completed the nonplussing change of attire, she pulled Sara to her feet and said “Now sweetie, I know you’re upset, but you don’t have to worry making it to the potty anymore.”
As Sara walked out of the bathroom, her face still flushed, she wondered what to do.

info.brief_description: Inspired by the Huggies Pull-Ups advertisements, follow a journey from baby to big kid!
info.description: A child has been newly enrolled in the Big Kid Potty Training Academy. Follow their journey from a diaper wearing baby, through pre-training, into actual daytime training, dealing with using the potty while out and about or at daycare, and then graduating into underwear! Also follow kids dealing with remedial training after regression, and Night School for bedwetters!
